Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my monitor, watching the minutes tick by. As a telemarketer, I was supposed to take my break at the scheduled time, but today the call volume was unusually light. My supervisor had even mentioned we could be flexible with our breaks. I felt a rare sense of freedom, but it was tinged with anxiety. Today was also election day, and I needed to get to the polling station before it closed. The polls were open all day, and my workload was manageable, but I couldn’t shake the feeling that I was being pulled in two directions. If I took my break now, I could vote and return without disrupting my calls. But what if the call volume suddenly spiked? Would my supervisor still be as understanding? I wanted to fulfill my civic duty, but I also didn’t want to risk being seen as unreliable at work. My mind raced, weighing the expectations of my job against my responsibility as a voter, feeling the pressure build as I tried to decide what to do next.
